title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
Tonight’s goals

To offer guidance and
To encourage you to make your discoveries accessible and understandable

To the entire DataFest audience (from N00b to expert)

yet uphold the credibility and accuracy of your work.

title: Presenting @ DataFest
section: 1. Know the level of understanding of your audience.
text:
1. Know the level of understanding of your audience.

After 40+ hours

Your peers will be experts BUT they do not have judging power.

Do not worry about peers judging you when you are presenting.

The judges have judging power. Two flavors:

The stakeholders e.g., 2015 Edmunds.com managers/lawyers judging
The professional Statisticians, Data Scientists, etc.

title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
2. Tailor your presentation.

Example. Edmunds.com DataFest 2015.

Two teams vying for the top prize (Best Insight).

Team One: a sophisticated analysis, machine learning techniques involving consumer choice modeling. Their team leader had wheeled in a modified server (this is 2015) with 32GB of memory to compete at DataFest.

title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
2. Tailor your presentation accordingly. (cont’d)

Team Two: a basic analysis, their presentation slide just had a few numbers from tables, a test, and pretty graphics.
Who do you think won?

Team Two.

The Team One cried foul and said they were “ripped off”.
The judging panel responded that the data provider “didn’t understand Team One’s analysis and as result, could not use the recommendation”

title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
3. KISS

Team One opened with “We utilized walking-forward cross-validation” (AKA time series cross validation or time series split)
TMI
It might be wiser to mention it only when the experts ask if you performed any cross-validation.
Think about it

title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
3. KISS! (cont’d)

If you are going to step up there and begin talking about performing a rolling time series split of the data, you may be compressing your audience from a few hundred to a few dozen people in that room.

It’s OK, but if you are going to do that, your compressed audience MUST INCLUDE the data provider.

If the data provider understands your talk, guess what…

the experts will too.

Give enough detail to establish credibility with the experts but avoid overwhelming the non-experts.

title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
4. Where to Start (suggestions)

Suggestion: clear statements of

What your analysis aimed to achieve AND
Why your analysis matters

Do this to engage your audience from the beginning.

title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
(suggestion) A PICTURE IS WORTH 1000 words.

Use charts, graphs, and/or infographics to make complex data more understandable.
Visuals should be clear, labeled correctly, and uncomplicated.
Slides from the 2017 winner (Best Insight, the top prize at the time)

title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
(Suggestion) What’s Your Story?



Introduce the key elements or variables of your analysis
Discuss your solution with a logical flow

from your solution/idea
to results and impact

title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
What’s Your Story? (Cont’d)






Your “story” should be interesting to the stakeholder.
Your findings should be relatable and understandable.

title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
5. Finish Well!

Summarize/Emphasize the most important results of your analysis
Do make it clear why these findings matter!
Explain how your findings fit the needs of the data provider.

title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
6. Be Prepared for Questions

Technical questions from stats & data science experts

General questions from the non-stats & data science experts

Ask yourselves, ask your friends, ask the mentors on the floor

title: Presenting @ DataFest
text:
7. Try to Practice your Presentation

Clarity
Timing
& build confidence in your delivery. (2/9/2024)

title: Presenting @ DataFest
section: 8. In the end, in whatever you do, have fun doing it.
text:
8. In the end, in whatever you do, have fun doing it.

You will only be this young, this strong, in this place and in this time once.

If you are not enjoying your time, then you are truly wasting your time.

title: Data Fest 2024
text:
To learn more about Quarto websites please visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.
To learn more about WebR please visit https://quarto-webr.thecoatlessprofessor.com/qwebr-first-steps.html.
And this site is hosted by GitHub (free) and easy setup and maintenance https://pages.github.com/

title: Effect Size
text:
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


data <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/lewv/S24STATS101A/main/data/EffectData.csv")
data$Manager <- factor(data$Manager, levels = paste0("Man.", 1:25))
data$ProductID <- factor(data$ProductID, levels = c("Prod.1","Prod.2","Prod.3","Prod.4","Prod.5","Prod.6","Prod.7","Prod.8","Prod.9","Prod.10"))
print(data[1:12,])

   Manager ProductID Sold
1    Man.1    Prod.1   29
2    Man.1    Prod.1   35
3    Man.1    Prod.1   47
4    Man.1    Prod.1   42
5    Man.1    Prod.1   32
6    Man.1    Prod.1   32
7    Man.2    Prod.1   72
8    Man.2    Prod.1   64
9    Man.2    Prod.1   65
10   Man.2    Prod.1   76
11   Man.2    Prod.1   69
12   Man.2    Prod.1   73



tapply(data$Sold, data$Manager, sum) |> sort()

 Man.6 Man.19 Man.11  Man.7  Man.5 Man.13 Man.18 Man.17  Man.1 Man.25  Man.3 
  8820   9000   9102   9210   9840  10746  10830  11796  11910  12546  12858 
Man.22 Man.24 Man.12 Man.15 Man.20 Man.10  Man.9  Man.8 Man.16  Man.4  Man.2 
 15054  15168  15642  16092  17046  18078  19434  20358  20400  20874  24402 
Man.23 Man.21 Man.14 
 25260  26430  26436 



# in dplyr
data %>%
  group_by(Manager) %>%
  summarize(TotalSold = sum(Sold)) %>%
  arrange(desc(TotalSold))

# A tibble: 25 × 2
   Manager TotalSold
   <fct>       <int>
 1 Man.14      26436
 2 Man.21      26430
 3 Man.23      25260
 4 Man.2       24402
 5 Man.4       20874
 6 Man.16      20400
 7 Man.8       20358
 8 Man.9       19434
 9 Man.10      18078
10 Man.20      17046
# ℹ 15 more rows



ggplot(data, aes(x = Manager)) +
  geom_bar(aes(weight = Sold), fill = "blue") +
  labs(x = "Manager", y = "Units Sold", title = "Total Sold by Manager") + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))





ggplot(data, aes(x = Manager, y = Sold, fill = ProductID)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  labs(x = "Manager", y = "Units Sold", title = "Total Sold by Product within Manager") + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))





# Compute proportion of product sold over total sold within Manager
data2 <- data %>% 
  group_by(Manager) %>% 
  mutate(total_sold = sum(Sold), 
         proportion = Sold / total_sold)


# Use mutated data to create 100% stacked bar plot
ggplot(data2, aes(x = Manager, y = proportion, fill = ProductID)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "fill") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +
  labs(x = "Manager", y = "Product Proportion", fill = "Product") +
  ggtitle("100% Stacked Bar Plot") + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))





# use geom_tile for a heatmap with non-numeric variables on X and Y
library(RColorBrewer)
my_palette <- brewer.pal(n = 11, name = "Spectral")

ggplot(data = data, aes(x = ProductID, y = Manager, fill = Sold)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_gradientn(colors = my_palette)  +
  labs(title = "Heatmap of Products Sold by Manager", 
       x = "Product ID", y = "Manager", fill = "Number Sold") +
  theme_minimal()





# use geom_contour - note modification of data
ggplot(data = data, aes(x = as.numeric(ProductID), y = as.numeric(Manager), z = Sold)) +
  geom_contour_filled() +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Spectral", guide = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE)) +
  labs(title = "Contour Map of Number of Products Sold by Manager", 
       x = "Product ID", y = "Manager", fill = "Number Sold") +
  theme_minimal()





# tiled heatmap suggests a two-way ANOVA
# also check interaction (probably not sig.)
result <- aov(Sold ~ Manager + ProductID + Manager:ProductID, data = data)
summary(result)

                    Df  Sum Sq Mean Sq  F value Pr(>F)    
Manager             24 2215305   92304 3696.664 <2e-16 ***
ProductID            9   92982   10331  413.755 <2e-16 ***
Manager:ProductID  216    2378      11    0.441      1    
Residuals         8750  218484      25                    
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1



# rerun without interaction
result2 <- aov(Sold ~ Manager + ProductID, data = data)


summary(result2)

              Df  Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F)    
Manager       24 2215305   92304  3747.1 <2e-16 ***
ProductID      9   92982   10331   419.4 <2e-16 ***
Residuals   8966  220862      25                   
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1



# check comparisons
# too many combinations choose(25, 2) = 300
TukeyResult <- TukeyHSD(result2)
dim(TukeyResult$Manager)

[1] 300   4

head(TukeyResult$Manager)

                 diff       lwr       upr        p adj
Man.2-Man.1 34.700000 33.346397 36.053603 0.000000e+00
Man.3-Man.1  2.633333  1.279731  3.986936 3.440545e-10
Man.4-Man.1 24.900000 23.546397 26.253603 0.000000e+00
Man.5-Man.1 -5.750000 -7.103603 -4.396397 0.000000e+00
Man.6-Man.1 -8.583333 -9.936936 -7.229731 0.000000e+00
Man.7-Man.1 -7.500000 -8.853603 -6.146397 0.000000e+00



# Recall
data %>%
  group_by(Manager) %>%
  summarize(TotalSold = sum(Sold)) %>%
  arrange(desc(TotalSold)) %>%
  slice_head(n = 5)

# A tibble: 5 × 2
  Manager TotalSold
  <fct>       <int>
1 Man.14      26436
2 Man.21      26430
3 Man.23      25260
4 Man.2       24402
5 Man.4       20874



# we only want to understand the 5 managers at the top of sales
# Check specific comparisons
TukeyResult$Manager[row.names(TukeyResult$Manager) %in% 
c("Man.21-Man.14",
"Man.23-Man.14",
"Man.23-Man.21",
"Man.2-Man.14",
"Man.21-Man.2",
"Man.23-Man.2",
"Man.4-Man.2"),]

                     diff        lwr       upr        p adj
Man.4-Man.2   -9.80000000 -11.153603 -8.446397 0.000000e+00
Man.21-Man.2   5.63333333   4.279731  6.986936 0.000000e+00
Man.23-Man.2   2.38333333   1.029731  3.736936 3.691728e-08
Man.21-Man.14 -0.01666667  -1.370269  1.336936 1.000000e+00
Man.23-Man.14 -3.26666667  -4.620269 -1.913064 0.000000e+00
Man.23-Man.21 -3.25000000  -4.603603 -1.896397 0.000000e+00


Looks like there are two managers tied at the top (14 + 21) followed by 23 and then 2.
